channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Pioneering stuntwoman Jeannie Epper, of 'Wonder Woman' and 'Charlie's Angels' dies
item.description: "We were united in the way that women had to be in order to thrive in a man's world, through mutual respect, intellect and collaboration," Wonder Woman star Lynda Carter posted in a tribute.
item.content:encoded:
"We were united in the way that women had to be in order to thrive in a man's world, through mutual respect, intellect and collaboration," Wonder Woman star Lynda Carter posted in a tribute.

(Image credit: M. Phillips/WireImage)
item.dc:creator: Mandalit del Barco

item.title: Some students who protested at colleges don't regret potential punishment
item.description: Some students face criminal charges, suspensions and even expulsions for participating in pro-Palestinian protests and encampments. Their reason? A "just cause".
item.content:encoded: Some students face criminal charges, suspensions and even expulsions for participating in pro-Palestinian protests and encampments. Their reason? A "just cause".
item.dc:creator: Sergio Martínez-Beltrán

item.title: Toxic culture is the norm at the FDIC, outside review cites 500 employee complaints
item.description: A law firm investigation of the FDIC documents a toxic workplace culture where hundreds of employees complained of sexual harassment, discrimination and other misconduct.
item.content:encoded:
A law firm investigation of the FDIC documents a toxic workplace culture where hundreds of employees complained of sexual harassment, discrimination and other misconduct.

(Image credit: Saul Loeb)
item.dc:creator: Scott Horsley

item.title: Donald Trump's Mar-a-Lago classified documents case is delayed indefinitely by judge
item.description: The classified documents trial had been scheduled to begin May 20. But months of delays had slowed the case as prosecutors pushed for the trial to begin before the November presidential election
item.content:encoded:
The classified documents trial had been scheduled to begin May 20. But months of delays had slowed the case as prosecutors pushed for the trial to begin before the November presidential election

(Image credit: Joe Raedle)
item.dc:creator: Russell Lewis

item.title: After calls for gun safety, Tennessee votes to arm teachers
item.description: Despite calls for gun safety legislation after the Covenant School shooting, Tennessee passed a measure allowing teachers to carry firearms in schools.
item.content:encoded:
Despite calls for gun safety legislation after the Covenant School shooting, Tennessee passed a measure allowing teachers to carry firearms in schools.

(Image credit: George Walker IV)
item.dc:creator: Blaise Gainey

item.title: Man admits racial harassment of Utah women's NCAA basketball team
item.description: Prosecutors in northern Idaho say they won't bring charges against a man who admitted to using a racial slur against University of Utah women's basketball players.
item.content:encoded:
Prosecutors in northern Idaho say they won't bring charges against a man who admitted to using a racial slur against University of Utah women's basketball players.

(Image credit: Steph Chambers)
item.dc:creator: Kirk Siegler

item.title: Nebraska Republican brings resolution to censure Ilhan Omar
item.description: This comes after recent remarks Omar gave on a college campus where she referred to Jewish students not engaging in an anti-Israel protest "pro-genocidal."
item.content:encoded:
This comes after recent remarks Omar gave on a college campus where she referred to Jewish students not engaging in an anti-Israel protest "pro-genocidal."

(Image credit: Kent Nishimura)
item.dc:creator: Barbara Sprunt

item.title: Increasing Election Violence in Mexico
item.description:
Mexico's general election will be held at the beginning of June and it will mark the end of a campaign season of record violence. Some thirty candidates have been assassinated in the past month. Our reporter goes to one of Mexico's most violent towns to talk to candidates who are brave enough to run for office.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
Mexico's general election will be held at the beginning of June and it will mark the end of a campaign season of record violence. Some thirty candidates have been assassinated in the past month. Our reporter goes to one of Mexico's most violent towns to talk to candidates who are brave enough to run for office.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org.

(Image credit: Eyder Peralta)
item.dc:creator: Eyder Peralta

item.title: 'Long Island' renders bare the universality of longing
item.description: In a heartrending follow-up to his beloved 2009 novel, Brooklyn, Colm Tóibín handles uncertainties and moral conundrums with exquisite delicacy, zigzagging through time to a devastating climax.
item.content:encoded: In a heartrending follow-up to his beloved 2009 novel, Brooklyn, Colm Tóibín handles uncertainties and moral conundrums with exquisite delicacy, zigzagging through time to a devastating climax.
item.dc:creator: Heller McAlpin

item.title: Biden decries surge of antisemitism since the October 7 Hamas attacks on Israel
item.description: President Biden spoke out against harassment of Jewish students on college campuses, part of what he called a "ferocious surge of antisemitism" seen since Oct. 7.
item.content:encoded:
President Biden spoke out against harassment of Jewish students on college campuses, part of what he called a "ferocious surge of antisemitism" seen since Oct. 7.

(Image credit: Saul Loeb)
item.dc:creator: Tamara Keith
